Read Full LicensePage 2/20Abstract Based on 1185 research articles related to traditional Chinese medicine (TCM) from 2020 to 2023 retrieved from the Web of Science (WOS) and Scopus databases, a comprehensive systematic literature review was conducted with the primary aim of exploring the main contributors, research status, hot topics and research frontiers concerning the international spread of TCM against the COVID-19 pandemic through a metrical and visualization analysis. CiteSpace 6.1. R6 software is applied to visualize the publication countries, subjects, authors, institutes, publication sources, keywords and references of the literature and to draw a visual knowledge graph. PRISMA 2020 was used to evaluate the scienti�city of this study itself, and the PRISMA 2020 scores generally showed good quality of the systematic review, conforming to 29 out of 37 items, partly in accordance with 2 items of TCM. The statistics of this study show that 81% of articles published are from China, followed by 8.2% from the USA and 5.3% from India. Moreover, the research hotspots of coronavirus in the articles involve molecular docking, sar, systematic review and herbal medicine. Moreover, the principal proposition of translation strategies in TCM's international spread is the combination of domestication and foreignization to maintain the originality of TCM's nature and to give consideration to the cognition of audiences. Instead of blindly merging into the Western medicine system, the international spread of TCM ought to broaden its span and to convey the theoretical framework, philosophical thoughts and traditional culture as a whole. In addition, cooperation between research institutes can be further strengthened to deliver an integrated and united research pattern. I. Introduction The COVID-19 pandemic, de�ned as a "Public Health Emergency of International Concern" by the World Health Organization (WHO), has caused hundreds of thousands of people to die globally. COVID-19 has become the largest global health crisis since the 21st century, resulting in enormous economic losses worldwide and emotional trauma worldwide. However, since the WHO recommended the development of potential vaccines and antiviral medicines at the second meeting of the Emergency Committee on January 30, 2020, there has been no con�rmed effective antiviral therapy for COVID-19(Zhuang et al., 2021). Because of the advantages of TCM in the treatment of complicated diseases, Chinese medical institutes spare no effort in conducting many studies to determine the most effective prescription. The successive Chinese top leadership, especially the president Xi Jinping (2019), has attached great importance to the industrialization and modernization of traditional Chinese medicine, which has been proven to have profound universal value and unique curative effects in some epidemic situations, such as malaria, sars and typhoid, and should be well protected, developed and inherited. It is essential to give full play to the unique advantages of TCM in disease prevention, treatment and rehabilitation, especially in the global health crisis. TCM has been not only a scienti�c accomplishment but also a cultural heritage for millennia. The Chinese government has upgraded the promotion and innovation of TCM since the 18th National Congress of the Communist Party of People's Republic of China, along with nearly 30 policies and measures. The outbreak of the COVID-19 pandemic is a huge challenge to the medical system in all countries globally. The treatment of coronavirus has become a major global public health concern. At the same time, the COVID-19 pandemic is also an opportunity to further demonstrate the advantages of traditional Chinese medicine, which holds an important status in global medical treatment, while the global acknowledgement of TCM is still far from what it deserves to be. Tu Youyou, who was awarded the Nobel Prize in Medicine in 2015, substantially boosts the popularity of TCM worldwide. However, the e�cacy of TCM has always been questioned worldwide, and some people even think of traditional Chinese medicine as pseudoscience because of its lack of randomized controlled trials in terms of drug safety and e�cacy(Qiu, 2007). The international communication of TCM faces obstacles, including the stereotype of "unscienti�c" and "empiricist"(Chen, Tong, Ren, Yu, & Cui, 2019). Thus, based on the active countries, authors, institutions, high-frequency references and keywords involved in the research articles about coronavirus published in the WOS and Scopus databases, a systematic investigation is critical to the future promotion of traditional Chinese medicine, which helps to improve international communication in the medical �eld and to make traditional Chinese medicine bene�t the world in the postpandemic era and the future. Especially in this pandemic of COVID-19, the Chinese government has successively released ten editions of Guidance for Coronavirus Disease: Prevention, Control, Diagnosis and Management, recommending the characteristic treatment of TCM, among which "three drugs and three prescriptions" were proven to be effective through clinical screening. "Three drugs" refers to the Chinese herb medicin of Jinhuaqinggan Granules against in�uenza A (H1N1), Lianhuaqingwen used for the prevention and control of COVID-19 and Xuebijing anti-infective injection. "Three detoxing decoction), Huashibaidugranule inhibiting and replication of viruses, and Xuanfeibaidugranule. Qingfeipaidu decoction was derived from �ve classic prescriptions from the Treatise on Febrile and Miscellaneous Diseases. Xuebijing injection was �rst developed and marketed during SARS in 2013. Combined use with Western medicine, "Three Drugs" and "Three Prescriptions" of TCM during the pandemic can improve the rate of cure and reduce the cost of treatment. The evaluation report on TCM in the �ght against COVID-19 was released after the WHO expert evaluation meeting held on 6 Apr. 2022, which a�rms the contribution of TCM in the �ght against COVID-19, encouraging member states to consider thePage 3/20integrated Chinese and Western medicine model (integrated medicine model) developed and applied in China.(Gaoli, Yingjian, & Fuchun, 2023) A total of 113 member countries of the WHO recognized acupuncture and other TCM diagnosis and treatment methods. TCM has already spread to over 196 countries and regions(Gaoli et al., 2023). The world witnessed an effective rate of 97.87% in the treatment and rehabilitation of patients(Liu, 2021) at the beginning of 2020 when TCM was involved in 92.41% of the treatment of COVID-19, but until now, it still lacks recognition and application on a global scale. However, there is a lack of research concerning the performance and international recognition of TCM during the pandemic. The statistical analysis of TCM-related articles published in international journals can help researchers grasp the focus and promote the international communication of TCM. Currently, there has not been a scientometric study using mathematical and statistical methods to analyse the intellectual landscape, basic characteristics, current status and emerging trends regarding TCM research as a treatment for the pandemic. Thus, this study addresses this gap and provides a full picture of the research on TCM speci�cally as a treatment for COVID-19. CiteSpace 6.1. Study Evaluation Giving full play to the original advantages of traditional Chinese medicine, promoting the life science of our country to achieve innovative breakthroughs, carrying forward the Chinese �ne traditional culture, and enhancing national and cultural self-con�dence, is of great signi�cance to promote mutual learning between civilizations and people, to promote the building of a community with a shared future for mankind, and to carry out coordinated efforts of Chinese and Western medicine. First published more than a decade ago, PRISMA has become one of the most cited reporting guidelines in biometrical literature, helping authors conduct transparent and complete reporting of systematic reviews(Sarkis-Onofre, Catalá-López, Aromataris, & Lockwood, 2021). Data Collection All the data in this study were retrieved on February 20, 2023, from the WOS database, as the largest comprehensive information resource and most trusted publisher-independent global citation database(Chen et al., 2019), which is the world's leading citation database, containing a curated collection of over 21,000 peer-reviewed, high-quality scholarly journals published worldwide and the Scopus database, which covers the world's most extensive scienti�c and medical literature abstracts, references and indexes. The topics of studies ("TS", which includes Title, Abstract, Keywords and Keywords Plus) in WOS are chosen as "TS=("TCM" and "COVID-19") and their Boolean combination. The span of the literature with a total of 1185 records retrieved is from January 2020 to February 20, 2023. Of the 1185 records, 663 are articles, 403 reviews, 40 letters, and 54 editorial materials. In the Scopus database, the TITLE-ABS-KEY (title, abstract and keywords) are limited to (traditional AND Chinese AND medicine) AND TITLE-ABS-KEY (COVID-19). There were 1282 studies in total, with 841 articles, 347 reviews, 37 letters, 12 conference papers, 11 editorials, 10 notes, etc., among which 6 errata and 1 retracted article were excluded for accurate analysis, leaving 1275 results. After rough screening of the titles and abstracts of the articles, 5 articles were scanned out for their relative irrelevance to the topic, such as "Post-COVID-19 Chinese domestic tourism market recovery: potential in�uence of traditional Chinese medicine on tourist behaviour" by Wen Jun et al, which focuses on the in�uence of TCM on the tourism market rather than treatment of COVID-19. After manual screening, 1270 articles remained. The risk of bias lies in the possibility that some articles may not mention COVID-19 in their titles, keywords or abstracts and are missed out on the systematic review as a result. The research protocol is not prepared. All identi�ed records were downloaded from the WOS database on February 20, 2023, and imported into CiteSpace for further studies. VI. Discussion 6.1 The translation of TCM In the 5.6 keyword analysis, it is shown that almost all the medical terminologies mentioned in the published articles are translated with the strategy of domestication. Domestication and foreinization are two concepts of translation strategie proposed by Lawrence Venuti in 1995 regarding the degree to which translators make a text conform to the target culture. In the international communication of traditional Chinese medicine, these two strategies should be considered together during the course of translation. However, through the articles retrieved with the topic of "traditional Chinese medicine" in the list of high-frequency keywords, it is di�cult to see any transliteration or speci�c terminology used only in TCM. According to the literature about TCM published in the WOS and Scopus databases from 1989 to 2018, compared with foreignization, domestication in translation was the dominant strategy in translating Chinese medicine ingredients. For example, Wutou alkali was translated to aconitine, and Danggui acid was turned into angelic acid. Foreignization bene�ts interdisciplinary research with compound analysis while losing national characteristics within TCM.(Wang & Tingyu, 2019) Overly catering to the needs of the Western medicine system would diminish the nature of TCM, which in essence holds a different theoretic system from Western medicine. TCM focuses on the harmony of the human body as a whole. There is no equivalent terminology in Western medicine. Thus, transliteration is necessary in some cases to preserve the original meaning of TCM and stay loyal to the source culture. Current translation can adopt dual translation as a transition, whichPage 14/20can preserve the culture while helping target language readers understand the content, such as translating "Fenghuo Yan ( ��� )" (drastic purgative treating method)"(En & Sulin, 2022). In regard to the specialized concepts that only exist in TCM, domestication can preserve the particularity of TCM and build a close connection between the source language and target readers, such as translating "Pizhu Yunhua ( ���� )" to "the transportation and transformation the control of spleen" and "Ganfeng Neidong ( ���� )" to "endogenous wind of liver" (Yu et al. 2017:1468-1469). The classic literature of TCM contains a complete theoretical system that can only be fully conveyed by its own metaphors. Traditional Chinese doctors focus on the human body from a holistic view. Instead of treating the disease itself only, some traditional Chinese doctors choose to heal the body and improve the overall state. There was a huge gap between the need in the TCM translation market and the talents nurtured by traditional teaching methods. Thus, translators with rich TCM knowledge were an indispensable part of the international communication of TCM. Moreover, the translation of TCM lacks systematic research. Until 2022, only 13 out of 24 colleges and universities of TCM in China had established undergraduate English programs, and only 6 of them had built English master's degree programs (Si and Si, 2022). A talent training system in TCM universities remains to be established. Additionally, different research groups should enhance cooperation, reduce duplicate research and establish standardized translation networks. There are more than 1000 pharmacopoeia books about TCM, of which only approximately 20 books were translated(Liu, 2021). Western At present, there are only three TCM translation corpora built in China: the English-Chinese parallel corpus of traditional Chinese medicine established by Heilongjiang University of Traditional Chinese Medicine, the Chinese-English bilingual corpus platform of traditional Chinese medicine established by Jiangxi Normal University and the parallel corpus of classical Chinese medicine literature created by Shanghai University of Traditional Chinese Medicine(Wang & Tingyu, 2019). The World Health Organization, World Federation of Chinese Medicine Societies and International Organization for Standardization/Technical Committee are the international standards for the translation of TCM(En & Sulin, 2022). However, the existing translation standard focuses mainly on qualitative research, which lacks empirical research in general. Moreover, some medicines often appear in different translations based on different standards, which greatly undermines the spread of traditional Chinese medicine worldwide. There is an urgent need to build a comprehensive corpus for international communication, along with a standardized discourse system and terminology criteria. 6.2 Research orientation On the one hand, the development and modernization of the TCM industry has bene�ted greatly from the Western medicine system. Computer- aided, structure-based drug discovery helped to narrow down a large amount of natural compounds of TCM into a relatively short time with limited resources(Ling, 2020). On the other hand, research articles on TCM presented or published in international conferences or some professional journals tend to sacri�ce some traditional Chinese culuture contained in the TCM in exchange for Western recognition. To date, more than 1,500 amateur teaching institutions for traditional Chinese medicine have been established in foreign countries, which could nurture approximately 30,000 TCM medical staff around the world (Si and Si, 2022). During its merging into the Western medical system, traditional Chinese medicine has been experiencing the process of modernization and westernization to bridge the gap between eastern and western mediacal systems, even sometimes at the loss of the original theoretical framework or the expression of the original discourse. Due to discrepancies in culture, history and philosophical views of health care and medication, the possible harm of traditional or herbal medicine to the human body has been wildly exaggerated by Western governments, rather than by telling their citizens to comprehensively understand and cognize, even to utilize the eastern traditional medical system and theories that have been proven to be scienti�cally useful in the long river of history. Thus, facing inconsistent or even polarized international patterns, it is necessary to spread Eastern cultures and philosophical thoughts in proper English discourse along with international communication or the process of the treatment of traditional Chinese medicine. Yin Xiong and Min Gao et al. (2021) performed research on traditional Chinese medicine or herbal medicine related to COVID-19 using the Web of Science Core Collection, MEDICINE, Current Contents Connect, and SCIELO Citation Index databases and found that among 634 records of TM/HMs, 48.9% of the data were contributed by institutes in China, compared with only 13.56% of the USA. TCM prescriptions and therapies were included and recommended in the guidelines released by the State Administration for Market Regulation and adopted in all stages of prevention, treatment and rehabilitation of COVID-19. Chinese people today are accustomed to adopting "integrative" treatment by receiving TCM and biomedicine at the same time. In the international spread of traditional Chinese medicine, a cognitive change in the use of Chinese herbals as one of the most common interventions is of the utmost importance. Most herbal medicines sold in Western countries are marketed as food or dietary supplements rather than for medical uses. In general, Western countries lack traditional use and well-designed clinical trials(Xiong et al., 2021). Although TCM has suggested great clinical experiences and effective and applicable herbal formulas for the inhabitation and treatment of respiratory diseases, the unfavorable environment for traditional medicine in western counties cannot be changed overnight yet. Thus, for better acceptance of TCM, the spread of TCM culture, philosophy and theory should be along with the pharmacy to build a friendly foundation among the Western public. 6.3 Incompatible media imagePage 15/20Although TCM has gradually gained scienti�c acknowledgement worldwide and shown a rather steady publication trend in international journals, public opinion toward TCM is still distorted by Western mass media. For example, Lianhuaqingwen was researched and developed by Shijiazhuang Yiling Pharmaceutical Company, which contains Forsythia suspensa and Lonicera japonica, to treat in�uenza and contributed �rst in 2003 in the �ght against severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS). Developed from two prescriptions, Maxingshi Sweet decoction and Yinqiao powder, which contain at least 11 herbal components, have been authorized by the National Medical Products Administration of China (NMPA) to treat SARS, tape an in�uenza virus, H1N1 pandemic in 2009, H7N7, H3N2 and coronavirus disease-19 caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-COV-2) in 2020 and have also been widely used as treatments for common cold with wind-heat syndrome, chronic rhinosinusitis (CRS), amygdalities and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease(Shen & Yin, 2021). However, despite satisfactory clinical effects, the acceptance of traditional herbal products among Western countries is still low. Some media outlets deliberately discredited TCM and made up all kinds of conspiracy theories to safeguard the interests of large Western pharmaceutical companies. The accusation was pointed out at Zhong Nanshan, the most celebrated commercial health professionals who, as an epidemiologist, was appointed to head an expert group at the National Health Commission due to his contributions after managing SARS in 2003. The Western media claimed that Zhong recommended Lianhuaqingwen because of his commercial ties with pharmaceutical factories(Primross Riordan, 2022). The spread of these kinds of rumours not only undermined the image of Chinese epidemiologists and reduced government credibility but also damaged the reputation of TCM as a whole. To date, there has been no con�rmed effective antiviral therapy for COVID-19, and the main approaches are only symptomatic and supportive treatment. Thus, because of the above reasons, the Western media frequently took advantage of the occasion to deny the e�cacy of TCM, even to wage a virulent hate campaign against TCM. Therefore, in the external communication of traditional Chinese medicine, by spreading the culture, philosophical thoughts and theory of TCM, Chinese media, network platforms, Chinese students studying abroad and overseas Chinese should have international discourse power and take the initiative to spread TCM, approximately eliminating Western audiences' misunderstanding of TCM. VII. Conclusion and Future Research In conclusion, the research and development of traditional Chinese medicine worldwide is in a steay improvement in the research �eld, but it is still mainly centralized in China's institutes, and the relative research and the acceptability of Chinese herbal products in Western countries remain insu�cient and rather unsatisfactory in general. As a result, Chinese research institutes and meia and pharmaceutical companies should increase collaboration and scienti�c connections with Western countries to form an intensive research, propaganda and sales network worldwide. The literature retrieved from the databases of WOS and Scopus reveals that the acceptability of TCM in the Western world, especially by the Western medicine system, is far less than people's expectations, which not only in�uences the international communication of TCM but also worsens the health of people all over the world, especially in an emergency. At the same time, some Western media maliciously throw doubt on the Chinese government recommendation on TCM to the Western, creating obstacles for TCM to be trusted by the world, which is undersirable and a great disservice to their people. In the future, only by integrating traditional Chinese medicine and Western medicine can we guarantee people's health and obtain a harmonious symbiotic environment. For the translation strategies in the international spread of TCM, the combination of domestication and foreignization in the translation of TCM should be the major consideration, which can ensure that the foreign cultural elements of the source text presented in the target text can also make the audience's reading barrier-free.
